script.hook: Everyone knows touchdowns are worth 6 points, right? Actually, that's just the beginning. Let's break down football's most exciting scoring play.

sections.title: Getting Into The End Zone
sections.content: A touchdown happens when any part of the ball crosses the goal line while your team has possession. It doesn't matter if the player's body is in - only the ball needs to break the plane of that white line.
sections.onScreen: animated ball crossing goal line + 'BALL BREAKS PLANE = TOUCHDOWN'

sections.title: The 6-Point Rule
sections.content: Touchdowns are worth exactly 6 points, not 7. That 7th point everyone talks about? That's separate - it comes from the extra point attempt that happens right after every touchdown.
sections.onScreen: scoreboard: 'TOUCHDOWN = 6 pts' then '+1 EXTRA POINT = 7 total'

sections.title: Bonus Round Choices
sections.content: After every touchdown, teams get one play from the 2-yard line. They can kick an extra point - almost automatic, worth 1 point - or try a 2-point conversion by running or passing it in. Harder, but worth 2 points.
sections.onScreen: split screen: extra point kick vs 2-point conversion attempt

sections.title: Strategic Thinking
sections.content: Most teams take the safe 1-point kick to make it 7 total. But late in games, you'll see desperate teams go for 2 to tie or take the lead. It's risk vs reward in its purest form.
sections.onScreen: game clock: 'LATE GAME' + decision tree: 'Need 2 to tie? GO FOR IT!'

sections.title: Quick Recap
sections.content: Remember: touchdown equals 6 points, then you choose your bonus. Most go for the easy extra point, but smart coaches know when to risk it all for 2.
sections.onScreen: formula: 'TD (6) + Choice (1 or 2) = 7 or 8 points' + CTA

questions.question: How many points is a touchdown worth by itself?
questions.explanation: A touchdown is always worth exactly 6 points. The 7th point comes from the extra point attempt after the touchdown.

questions.question: What needs to happen for a touchdown to count?
options: The player's whole body must be in the end zone
The ball must break the plane of the goal line
The player must catch the ball in the end zone
The ball must touch the ground in the end zone
questions.explanation: Only the ball needs to break the plane (cross) the goal line. It doesn't matter where the player's body is - if any part of the ball crosses that white line, it's a touchdown!

questions.question: A team just scored a touchdown. What's the maximum total points they can earn from this scoring drive?
options: It depends on how far they drove
questions.explanation: A touchdown is always worth 6 points, but teams can choose to go for a 2-point conversion instead of the 1-point extra point kick, making the maximum 8 points total.

questions.question: When do teams usually decide to go for a 2-point conversion instead of kicking the extra point?
options: On every touchdown to maximize points
Late in close games when they need exactly 2 points
questions.explanation: Teams typically go for 2 when they're behind late in the game and need exactly 2 points to tie or take the lead. It's a strategic risk-reward decision based on game situation.

keyTerms.definition: The 10-yard area at each end of the field where touchdowns are scored
The line separating the field from the end zone
Attempting to score 2 points after a touchdown instead of kicking the 1-point extra point
